Details: Multi-Factor Authentication adds an extra security layer to state portal logins. You'll need to collect MFA information from each state portal and add it to the WOTC platform.
The automation bot needs MFA credentials to log into state portals and submit WOTC forms on your behalf. Without MFA info the bot cannot complete automated submissions.
Time-based One-Time Password - uses an authenticator app like Google Authenticator or Authy. Most common type.
Text message codes sent to your phone number. Bot intercepts SMS messages.
Codes sent to your email address. Requires email integration.
One-time use codes (usually 10-12) provided when you first set up MFA. Save these!
Go to the state's WOTC portal URL and log in with your existing credentials
Look for menu options like: Account Settings, Security, Two-Factor Authentication, or Multi-Factor Authentication
Example: Usually found in: Profile → Security or Account → Settings

Details: Click 'Enable Two-Factor Authentication' or similar button. Portal will ask you to choose a method (TOTP/SMS/Email)

Topic: Step 4A: For TOTP - Get Secret Key
Details: Portal shows a QR code. Look for text that says 'Can't scan? Enter this code manually' - that's your secret key. Copy it!

Topic: Step 4B: For SMS - Get Phone Number
Details: Portal asks for phone number. Note which number you provided.

Topic: Step 4C: For Email - Get Email Address
Details: Portal asks for email address. Note which email you provided.
Portal displays backup codes (usually once). Download or copy them immediately!
Go to Admin → State Credentials, click Edit on the state, scroll to MFA section, enter the info, and Save
A 16-32 character string that generates time-based codes. This is what you'll enter into our platform - NOT the 6-digit codes.
Under the QR code during MFA setup. Look for 'Manual entry' or 'Can't scan?' link
Example: Text usually says: 'Enter this key manually: JBSWY3DPEHPK3PXP'

Details: DON'T: Scan QR code with authenticator app. DON'T: Enter the 6-digit code. DO: Copy the secret key text.
Example: Wrong: 123456 (that's a code, not the secret)

Details: The bot uses the secret to generate fresh 6-digit codes automatically whenever it needs to log in
The phone number that receives SMS codes from the state portal
Bot intercepts SMS messages sent to this number and extracts the verification code
The email address that receives verification codes from the state portal
Bot checks this email inbox and extracts codes from state portal emails
Example: Email subject: 'Your WOTC Portal Verification Code: 123456'

Details: One-time use codes provided when you first enable MFA. Each can only be used once.
Only ONCE when you first set up MFA. Portal won't show them again.
Example: Portal says: 'Save these codes now. You won't see them again.'

Details: Usually 10-12 codes provided
If primary MFA fails the bot can use a backup code as fallback
Example: Bot uses: 1234-5678 (then marks it as used)

Details: Admin Portal → State Credentials → Click 'Edit' on any state
Scroll down to find 'MFA Configuration' section in the edit dialog
Choose: TOTP, SMS, or Email from dropdown
For TOTP: Paste the secret key. For SMS: Enter phone number. For Email: Enter email address
Enter backup codes separated by commas or one per line
Click Save - everything is encrypted with AES-256-GCM immediately
https://www.twc.texas.gov/wotc
Go to TWC portal and log in with your credentials
Click Account → Security Settings → Enable Two-Factor Authentication
Select 'Authenticator App' (TOTP recommended)
Portal shows QR code. Look below it for: 'Enter this key: JBSWY3DPEHPK3PXP'
Portal shows 10 codes. Save them: 1234-5678, 9876-5432, etc.
In WOTC platform: Edit Texas → MFA Type: TOTP → Secret: JBSWY3DPEHPK3PXP → Save
Begin with states where you process the most WOTC claims
Example: Priority: CA, TX, FL, NY, OH

Topic: Do One State at a Time
Details: Don't try to set up all 50 states at once. Take breaks to avoid confusion.
Focus on states with automation enabled (CA, FL, GA, MI, NY, OH, TX) for immediate ROI
Example: These states have Playwright bots ready

Details: Use the State MFA Tracking Checklist CSV to track your progress
Example: Mark each state as: Not Started, In Progress, or Complete

Details: Save backup codes in a password manager or secure document. Each can only be used once.
After adding credentials for a state, test a submission to verify everything works
Example: Submit a test WOTC form through the automation

Details: Look for: Security, Account Settings, Two-Factor Auth, Login Security, Advanced Security
Example: Try searching portal help docs for 'MFA' or '2FA'

Details: Look for links like: 'Can't scan?', 'Manual entry', 'Enter code manually', or 'Trouble scanning?'
Example: These reveal the text secret key

Details: Some states may not require MFA yet. Mark as 'N/A' and just enter User ID/Password
Most portals let you regenerate backup codes in Security Settings. Old codes become invalid.
Example: Generate new set: Security → Regenerate Backup Codes

Details: Secret should be 16-32 alphanumeric characters (no spaces). If it has spaces, remove them.
Example: Wrong: JBSW Y3DP EHPK 3PXP, Right: JBSWY3DPEHPK3PXP

Details: Have: 1) Login credentials ready, 2) Password manager open, 3) Tracking spreadsheet, 4) Time (2-3 min per state)
Do: 1) Log into state portal, 2) Enable MFA, 3) Copy secret key, 4) Save backup codes, 5) Update spreadsheet
Verify: 1) Secret key saved, 2) Backup codes saved, 3) Spreadsheet updated, 4) Credentials added to platform, 5) Test submission
2-3 minutes per state. About 2-3 hours total for all 50 states if done in one sitting (not recommended - do in batches)
Example: Recommended: 10 states per day over 5 days

Details: No, many states don't require MFA yet. You'll discover this as you log into each portal.
Example: Estimate: 20-30% of states have MFA enabled

Topic: What if I make a mistake?
Details: You can always edit credentials in the platform. Go to State Credentials → Edit → Update MFA info → Save
Yes, all credentials and MFA secrets are encrypted with AES-256-GCM before storage. Even admins can't see the decrypted values in the database.
Not currently. Each state must be entered individually through the State Credentials interface for security reasons.
